qas.question: What's the temperature at which resin softens and expands called?
Along with vias, what makes up the components of a board?
What will happen to the components when the temperature of resin goes above that of glass transition?
When resin stays below Tg, its thermal expansion is similar to that of copper and what other material?
What do thick boards require to resist plating failure?
The resin in the composite hardens when?

plausible_answers.text: the thickness and stresses the plated-through holes

qas.question: Virtually no volume expansion projects to where?
Exposition to lower temperatures can cause failure of what?

context: <b5_0>At the <a0_0>glass transition temperature<b5_0/><a0_0/> the resin in the composite softens and significantly increases thermal expansion; exceeding Tg then exerts <a2_0>mechanical overload<a2_0/> on the board components - e.g. the <a1_0>joints<a1_0/> and the vias. Below Tg the thermal expansion of the resin roughly matches copper and <a3_0>glass<a3_0/>, above it gets significantly higher. As the reinforcement and copper confine the board along the plane, virtually all volume expansion projects to <b6_0>the thickness and stresses the plated-through holes<b6_0/>. Repeated soldering or other exposition to higher temperatures can cause failure of <b8_0>the plating<b8_0/>, especially with thicker boards; thick boards therefore require <a4_0>high <b7_0>Tg matrix<b7_0/><a4_0/>.
